question_text: A 23-year-old woman is evaluated for recent onset of petechiae on the legs.Peripheral blood smear is shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is immune thrombocytopenic purpura (Option C). Platelets appear as small purplish cells without a nucleus. As a rule of thumb, approximately 8 to 15 platelets are normally seen per 100-power field. This peripheral blood smear contains fewer than seven platelets, suggesting a very low platelet count. Additionally, the giant platelet shown on the smear (arrow) is typically associated with increased platelet production (secondary to the stress of increased peripheral platelet destruction) and immune disorders, such as immune thrombocytopenic purpura.
